title-group.article-title: The in-house designed patient-specific implants combined with navigation systems in orthognathic surgery: a case series of three patients

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Faculty of Dentistry, Mahidol University, Bangkok, Thailand
2Dental Department, Samut Sakhon Hospital, Samut Sakhon, Thailand

author-notes.corresp: Warutta Kasemsarn, Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, Faculty of Dentistry, Mahidol University, No. 6, Yothi Road, Ratchathewi District, Bangkok 10400, Thailand, TEL: +66-2-200-7845-6, E-mail: warutta.kas@gmail.com, ORCID: https://orcid.org/0000-0002-9500-8317

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: This case series aims to describe the virtual surgical planning process and report the surgical outcomes of in-house-designed patient-specific implants (PSIs) combined with navigation systems in orthognathic surgery.

sec.title: Patients and Methods
sec.p: Three patients undergoing two-jaw surgery were assessed across pre-surgical planning, surgical execution, and post-surgical evaluation phases. The accuracy was evaluated between the surgical plan (T0) and immediate post-operative three-dimensional (3D) radiographic image (T1) using 2 methods bone surface comparison and dental landmark comparison. The stability was assessed between T1 and 3D radiographic image at 9 months after surgery (T2) by Bone surface comparison method.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The accuracy assessed by Bone surface comparison shows that green areas (deviation between 0.0-0.4 mm) were mostly observed in the anterior region of the Le Fort I segment. The average deviations of dental landmark comparison are as follows in the left-right direction, 0.28±0.41 to the right; in the anterior-posterior direction, 0.13±0.48 to the posterior; and in the superior-inferior direction, 0.37±0.39 to the inferior. The stability assessed by bone surface comparison shows the green area in two of three patients, indicating minimal post-surgical changes.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The in-house-designed PSIs combined with navigation systems can achieve accuracy and stability in orthognathic surgery.

sec.title: I. Introduction
sec.p: Orthognathic surgery corrects dentofacial deformities through skeletal repositioning to achieve functional occlusion and facial harmony. Traditional planning employs two-dimensional (2D) radiographs, model surgery, and occlusal splints for surgical transfer. Intermediate occlusal splints, used for maxillary repositioning, require condylar head rotation in centric relation (CR), while bone plates are contoured to maintain maxillary position post-repositioning. This approach presents multiple challenges: Preoperative inaccuracies arise from face-bow transfer errors and 2D imaging limitations in three-dimensional (3D) facial assessment. Intraoperative reliability diminishes when abnormal temporomandibular joint kinematics or residual bony interferences affect splint seating. Multidimensional maxillary movements introduce vertical measurement parallax errors from radiographic superposition1. Finally, manual plate adaptation risks imperfect positioning that could enable postoperative skeletal relapse.

The recent rise of patient-specific implants (PSIs), designed using virtual surgical planning (VSP) and manufactured through 3D printing or computer-aided design and computer-aided manufacturing technology, has revolutionized the field. To create the workpieces, they can be designed or manufactured by a third-party company or within the hospital. The former option provides the advantage of reducing the upfront investment and minimizing the institutional workload; however, it may prolong the treatment planning duration and increase overall treatment costs. The latter, known as the in-house technique, reduces those limitations. PSIs with cutting and drilling guides offer precise adaptation to the patient’s anatomy, reducing intraoperative time and improving accuracy in achieving surgical outcomes2,3. This shift has been supported by studies demonstrating better fit and stability compared to traditional miniplates3,4. Previous studies have also shown the superior accuracy of PSIs compared to occlusal splints in patients with normal temporomandibular joints5-7. As a result, PSIs have gained popularity for various maxillofacial procedures, reflecting a broader trend toward individual solutions in surgical care.

Navigation systems in orthognathic surgery are valuable tools for enhancing surgical precision by superimposing medical images with VSP and providing real-time feedback8. This technology can be used in several ways, such as positioning the Le Fort I segment by the splintless technique9, verifying its position with a splint10, or with the PSIs11.

To contribute to the research on the utilization of PSIs and navigation systems, this case series presents 3 cases detailing the treatment planning process and device fabrication by in-house VSP technique, intraoperative application, and post-surgical outcomes of using PSIs and navigation systems in orthognathic surgery patients. The outcomes are divided into accuracy and stability, using the bone surface and dental landmark comparisons.

sec.title: II. Patients and Methods
sec.p: This case series involved three patients with skeletal class III deformity and normal temporomandibular joints who were planned for two-jaw surgery (Le Fort I osteotomy and bilateral sagittal split ramus osteotomy [BSSRO]) at the Faculty of Dentistry, Mahidol University. The patient’s demographic data is shown in Table 1. This research was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of the Faculty of Dentistry and Faculty of Pharmacy, Mahidol University (MU-DT/PY-IRB 2023/DT032). The methodology was divided into 3 phases: pre-surgical planning, surgery, and post-surgical evaluation.

sec.title: 1. Pre-surgical planning
sec.p: The clinical data, 3D medical computed tomography (CT) scans (Revolution EVO; GE Healthcare) with a resolution of 0.5-1.0 mm and dental models, were collected.

The VSP was planned using ProPlan CMF 3.0 (Materialise). The same VSP protocol was applied to all cases. The Standard Triangle Language (STL) segmentation was set to a threshold range between 226-3071 (bone threshold). Head orientation was aligned to the Frankfurt horizontal plane, and dental scans were registered using the occlusal registration module. The cylinders representing the screw holes were created on the maxilla and the Le Fort I osteotomy segment. Subsequently, the Le Fort I segment was repositioned to the desired position.(Fig. 1. A, 1. B)

The workpieces using Meshmixer (v3.5; Autodesk) from the STL files were exported from ProPlan CMF 3.0.(Fig. 1. C, 1. E) The 3 workpieces were then created: (1) Cutting guide that defined the Le Fort I osteotomy cut line and screw positions for the milled-customized plate. The component was manufactured from 3D-printed resin. (2) PSIs that secured the Le Fort I segment and the maxilla using 2.0 mm miniplate screws. The component was produced using grade 5 titanium, milled by Tdentallab. (3) Final occlusal splint used for moving the BSSRO segment to occlude with the maxilla. Since this study did not use PSIs for BSSRO movement, the component was produced using resin material with a 3D printer.

The files for the navigation systems (Curve Navigation; BrainLab) were prepared as follows: (1) 3D medical CT scans in Digital Imaging and Communications in Medicine (DICOM) file format. (2) STL files of the maxilla, Le Fort I segment (normal position and reposition according to the plan), cutting guide, and PSIs.

sec.title: 2. Surgical procedure
sec.p: The placement of the nasoendotracheal tube was carefully planned, with specific consideration for the skull reference base, and a preoperative consultation was conducted with the anesthesiologist.

Registration of the navigation systems was performed by overlaying the patient’s position with the prepared 3D radiographic image data. The bone surface was used for registration, which requires opening the tissue and exposing the upper jaw bone.(Fig. 2. A) The accuracy of the registration process was checked using the dental midline, the tips of the left and right upper canines, and the tips of the left and right first upper molars, which must coordinate between the clinical and the device.(Fig. 2. B)

During the orthognathic surgery, the cutting guide was placed on the maxilla and verified the position by using a pointer to check the position of the screws.(Fig. 2. C, 2. D) The Le Fort I osteotomy was performed by using a saw to cut along the slot of the cutting guide and then mobilized as standard procedure. In some patients where the plan is to impact the Le Fort I segment, the cutting guide design requires the removal of bone, which can be done by cutting the upper and lower edges of the cutting guide slot. Since the cutting guide was designed to account solely for the anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, removal of other bony interferences, particularly sections of the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone, was left to the surgeon’s discretion. During the placement of PSIs, small straight-tipped instruments such as a periodontal probe or an 18-gauge needle could help identify screw positions. The position of the Le Fort I segment was evaluated with the navigation systems by touching various tooth tips with the pointer to check that the Le Fort I segment had moved to the desired position according to the treatment plan.(Fig. 3) The mandible was operated using the BSSRO technique. The final occlusal splint and stock bone fixation plates were used.

sec.title: 3. Post-surgical evaluation
sec.p: Follow up on clinical symptoms was carried out at 1, 3, 6, and 9 months after surgery. If any abnormal symptoms were observed, removal of the plates and their replacement with stock bone fixation plates would be considered.

3D radiographic imaging within 1 month after surgery (T1) and the surgical plan (T0) were compared to evaluate the accuracy of using PSIs and navigation systems and at 9 months (T2) to assess the stability of the device. The post-operative images were converted to STL files using the same threshold setting as the pre-operative images (226-3071, bone threshold). The Frankfurt horizontal plane was established, and the superimposition process between interested images was performed by focusing on the skull base area, which must be completely aligned.

sec.title: 1) Accuracy analysis
sec.p: The accuracy of the customized plate was analyzed by comparing the discrepancies of the bone surface and dental landmark between T0 and T1. The analysis included the following methods: bone surface comparison; this method overlaid the T0 and T1, with a tolerance set at 2 mm. The resulting color coding displayed the deviations as follows:
• Green: Deviation between 0.0-0.4 mm
• Yellow: Deviation between 0.4-0.8 mm
• Orange: Deviation between 0.8-1.2 mm
• Red: Deviation between 1.2-1.6 mm
• Purple: Deviation between 1.6-2.0 mm
Dental landmark comparison: measurements were taken along three axes—left-right, anterior-posterior, and superior-inferior—at specific tooth positions, including:
• Cusp tips of the upper right central incisors (11)
• Cusp tips of the upper right and left canines (13, 23)
• Mesiobuccal cusp tips of the upper first right and left molars (16, 26)

sec.title: 2) Stability analysis
sec.p: The stability of the customized plate was assessed by using the bone surface comparison between T1 and T2. The dental landmark comparison was inapplicable due to the post-operative orthodontic treatment.

sec.title: III. Results
sec.p: Two-jaw surgery was performed according to the plan for each case. No adverse events that would warrant removal of the plates occurred throughout the study, and no patient required reoperation.

sec.title: 1. Accuracy analysis
sec.p: To evaluate the accuracy of the PSIs, dental landmark comparison was conducted for all three patients. The findings, based on each patient in Table 2, were averaged as follows: (1) Left-Right Direction: Deviation of 0.28±0.41 millimeters to the right. (2) Anterior-posterior direction: deviation of 0.13±0.48 millimeters to the posterior. (3) Superior-inferior direction: deviation of 0.37±0.39 millimeters to the inferior. (4) Bone surface comparison, focusing on the Le Fort I area, was used to compare between T0 and T1. Green areas, indicating a deviation of 0.0-0.4 mm, were predominantly found in the anterior region of the Le Fort I segment.(Fig. 4)

sec.title: 2. Stability analysis
sec.p: Fig. 5 shows the Bone surface comparison between T1 and T2. Patient 1 and 3 exhibited green areas in the anterior region of the Le Fort I segment. Patient 2 displayed green areas at the canine tooth position, indicating a deviation between 0.0-0.4 mm at the mentioned areas.

sec.title: IV. Discussion
sec.p: This case series demonstrates the potential of combining in-house designed PSIs with navigation systems in orthognathic surgery to enhance surgical accuracy and stability, consistent with results from other studies5,6. Comparative studies have shown that patients utilizing PSIs achieved greater accuracy than those relying on occlusal splints, with no complications reported from the overall jaw surgery12. The integration of navigation technology further assists in verifying the placement of cutting guides and fixation plates, ensuring alignment with the surgical plan. Kraeima et al.5 reported deviations for the PSIs group as 1.05 mm anterior-posterior, 0.87 mm superior-inferior, and 0.46 mm left-right, outperforming the splint group with deviations of 1.74 mm, 0.98 mm, and 1.07 mm, respectively. In this study, deviations from the planned position ranged from approximately 0.13 mm to 0.37 mm across different directions, with no deviations exceeding 1 mm. As none of these deviations exceeded 1 mm in any dimension, they can be considered clinically satisfactory13. Stability assessments at 1 and 9 months postoperatively showed most cases within a narrow range of 0.0-0.4 mm, indicating satisfactory long-term stability. From the literature review, stability assessments are rarely reported in studies involving PSIs and navigation systems, which distinguishes this study from previous research. Only one study by van der Wel et al.14 reported a comparison of the skeletal stability of patients receiving conventional plates and PSIs at 2 weeks and 1 year post-operative and indicated that the maxillary stability had median translations of less than 1 mm and median rotations of less than 1° in both groups.

The VSP workflow employed in this study strategically leveraged ProPlan CMF 3.0 software for comprehensive orthognathic surgery planning, while utilizing Meshmixer, free software, to create PSIs and cutting guides that an outsourced dental laboratory subsequently milled. The choice of subtractive manufacturing methods, particularly milling, offers significant advantages over expensive additive manufacturing techniques that require specialized 3D printing laboratories. This approach builds upon pioneering work by Brunso et al.4, who demonstrated the viability of subtractive methods with reported deviations of less than 1 mm in six cases involving jaw movements under 10 mm. This VSP hybrid production workflow was specifically designed to optimize cost-effectiveness while leveraging available institutional software resources; however, the initial investment required for both in-house PSIs design capabilities and navigation systems remains significant. The availability of established systems and software within the research faculty eliminated these costs from the study parameters, though this advantage may not extend to all clinical centers. Comparative analysis indicates that in-house PSIs production costs approximately one-third of commercial alternatives, representing substantial potential savings for institutions with adequate fabrication capabilities. Preoperative preparation time demonstrates marked improvement compared to outsourced alternatives due to eliminated data transfer delays and reduced coordination requirements, though navigation system setup time was not quantified in this study. The learning curve associated with navigation registration processes remains a critical factor influencing overall efficiency and successful implementation.

The materials for cutting guides generally fall into two categories: resin and titanium. Resin offers low cost and can be produced with standard 3D printers; however, it necessitates a thickness of at least 2-3 mm, which can complicate insertion during surgery. Improper osteotomy of the maxilla may lead to cutting into the pre-drilled holes of the cutting guide. Conversely, titanium allows for thinner cutting guides, preventing tools from damaging screw holes while achieving more precise cuts according to the surgical plan. This study opted for biocompatible photopolymer resin, which maintained structural integrity without breaking or bending when designed to be approximately 2 mm thick and connected at the top and bottom with a resin bridge.(Fig. 2. C, 2. D) Cutting guide designs for Le Fort I osteotomy can be categorized into two primary types: bone-borne and tooth-borne cutting guides4,6,11,15-17. Bone-borne guides are compact and user-friendly but may shift if not securely fitted to the bone. This study employed this method alongside the navigation systems to mitigate this risk. Tooth-borne cutting guides rest on the teeth, minimizing movement; however, their design must account for soft tissue during vestibular incision, necessitating careful contouring around the tissue during surgery. The tools used for attaching bone fixation plates to the maxilla generally conform to the bony buttresses, resulting in shapes that extend to the maxillary buttress at all four positions of the maxilla. Some studies have advocated for the production of PSIs for each position, similar to standard bone fixation plates, which can facilitate easier attachment due to their smaller size5,6. Other studies have suggested creating these plates as a single piece for enhanced jaw movement accuracy16. In this study, we designed the left and right plates separately for easier manipulation and to minimize errors at the anterior nasal spine area, which has a sharp bony edge and is prone to inaccurate STL segmentation.

The use of navigation systems in surgery has gained significant attention across multiple disciplines, including neurosurgery, orthopedics, for its ability to enhance precision and improve outcomes18,19. Azarmehr et al.20 reviewed the studies of navigation systems in oral and maxillofacial surgery between 2010-2015 and reported several indications for using the navigation systems, including trauma surgery, foreign body removal, cancer and reconstruction surgery, skull base surgery, and orthognathic surgery. Navigation system can also be combined with minimally invasive surgery to decompress the optic nerve in cases of traumatic optic neuropathy, as reported by Okui et al.21. In orthognathic surgery, there are various instances in which the navigation systems can be used to assist in the procedure, such as verifying the placement of cutting guides and plates and ensuring alignment with the surgical plan22,23. Zinser et al.9 used navigation systems and an interactive image-guided visualization display for moving the Le Fort I segment without an occlusal splint and found clinically acceptable precision ranges from 0.35-0.64 mm. Shirota et al.10 modified the technique by using an intermediate splint combined with the navigation systems to ensure the proper position of the maxilla and facilitate bony interference removal. Mazzoni et al.11,22 utilized PSIs with navigation systems to verify the accuracy of the cutting guide, similar to the approach taken in this study. However, criticisms have emerged regarding limitations, including the high initial cost of the equipment and the requirement for specialized training in its setup, which has hindered broader adoption24. This study highlighted specific considerations for the use of navigation systems in orthognathic surgery, setting it apart from other surgical applications. Achieving highly accurate registration is crucial, as deviations exceeding millimeters are unacceptable in orthognathic surgery. In our experience, the placement of the skull reference frame requires careful planning to account for other equipment and personnel, such as nasoendotracheal tubes and surgical assistants, ensuring signal reception remains unobstructed. During the registration process, touchless methods are preferable before securing the nasoendotracheal tube to minimize facial soft tissue distortion. Alternatively, bone or internal surface registration, achieved by exposing the bone through flap elevation, offers greater precision as these areas are less affected by external devices, though it may necessitate wider tissue exposure.

Acknowledged limitations include the restricted sample size of three patients, which constrains the generalizability of findings. Additionally, the high initial costs and technical demands of VSP software and navigation systems continue to present barriers to widespread adoption. Furthermore, the inapplicability of stability assessments based on dental landmark comparisons due to orthodontic tooth movement and possible error of the superimposed images from the conversion of DICOM to STL file, which could be seen in some areas of Fig. 5. Lastly, BSSRO was performed for the mandible using stock miniplates, as PSIs for the mandible remain controversial due to challenges in efficiency and accuracy, particularly given the requirement for preoperative CT data to be taken with the mandible in CR position4,25-27. This step can complicate treatment and may lead to issues such as misalignment of PSIs, improper fitting of screw holes, or failure to achieve the intended occlusion, as noted by Suojanen et al.28, who reported correct fitting in only 11 of 30 cases due to factors like temporomandibular joint positioning and residual bone interference. However, some studies have successfully demonstrated outcomes when utilizing PSIs for the mandible5,6,15. Therefore, PSIs for the mandible remain controversial due to challenges in maintaining the jaw position during preoperative radiographic imaging, which can affect the fit and accuracy of the plates.

Further research with larger sample sizes is necessary to validate the efficacy and stability of this combined approach and the workpiece design. Developing standardized protocols for mandibular PSIs fabrication, particularly to address issues related to radiographic positioning, will be crucial. Advances in surgical planning and intraoperative navigation should focus on improving registration accuracy and reducing setup complexity to make these technologies more user-friendly. Moreover, exploring alternative materials and production methods may lower costs and expand accessibility. Training programs to overcome the learning curve associated with navigation systems will also facilitate broader implementation in clinical practice.

sec.title: V. Conclusion
sec.p: This case series highlights that in-house designed PSIs with navigation systems can achieve accuracy and stability in orthognathic surgery, with deviations within 1 mm and no observed complications. While promising, the findings are limited by a small sample size. Further studies with larger populations are recommended to validate these results.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This research has been successfully completed with support from Tdentallab Co., Ltd. for fabricating the titanium plate, and Ingenious Technology Co., Ltd. for providing the navigation systems.

fn.p: W.K. participated in data collection, contributed to the study design, and wrote the article. T.T. contributed to drafting the manuscript. All authors read and approved the final manuscript.
This research project was supported and funded by the Faculty of Dentistry, Mahidol University.

p.bold: Ethics Approval and Consent to Participate

fn.p: This research was approved by the Institutional Review Board (IRB) of the Faculty of Dentistry and Faculty of Pharmacy, Mahidol University (MU-DT/PY-IRB 2023/DT032). Informed consent was not required for the case series study because images did not contain patient-specific information.
No potential conflict of interest relevant to this article was reported.

caption.p: Virtual surgical planning. Using ProPlan CMF 3.0 software (Materialise), Le Fort I osteotomy of the maxilla is depicted, highlighting the markings for all desired screw hole positions (A). The repositioned Le Fort I segment is displayed while preserving the designated screw positions (B). Le Fort I cutting guide (C, D) and PSIs (E, F) were created using Meshmixer software (v3.5; Autodesk).

Intraoperative use of both the cutting guide and navigation systems is demonstrated. Bone surface registration was conducted to ensure precision (A, B). The cutting guide is positioned on the maxilla and secured with screws (C) after rechecking with the navigation systems to verify that the device is in the planned position by using the pointer to verify the position of the screws (D).

Evaluation of the repositioned Le Fort I position using a navigation systems (A, B). This involves using the pointer to assess the dental midline area (C) or the screw hole area of the patient-specific implants (D).
The accuracy analysis between the surgical plan (T0) and the postoperative images (T1) using bone surface analysis. The results for Patient 1, 2, and 3 are shown in (A), (B), and (C), respectively.

The stability analysis between postoperative images taken at one month (T1) and those taken at nine months (T2) using bone surface analysis. The results for Patient 1, 2, and 3 are shown in (A), (B), and (C), respectively.
Dental landmark comparison compare between surgical planning (T0) and surgical results within one month (T1)
